data.title: Charles Edward Broadhurst: a remarkable 19th century failure
data.meta_description: The study of Charles Edward Broadhurst, on of Western Australia's most prolific and controversial entrepreneurs: Victorian and north-west pastoralist, north west and Shark Bay, pearler, steamship owner, fish canner, guano merchant, MLC
data.text:
For centuries right through to the 'Cossack Era' (pre-Broome) in the mid 1860s Aboriginal people on the north west coast of Australia did not dive for pearls rather they engaged in 'dry shelling' or wading at low water. The transition to 'naked diving' i.e. diving without an aids (e.g. mask, fins or snorkel) occurred at the instigation of European pearlers in mid 1868. When the number so Aborigines became inadequate, the pearlers imported 'Malays' or people from the islands north of Australia as indentured labour, continuing the naked diving tradition until the advent of the 'Broome Era' around 1883 when the 'hard hat' or diving apparatus became common. In the 20th century Indonesian troches shell divers continued the tradition, albeit with hand carved wooden goggles as their only aid.

As in several other settler colonial societies, Australia has come some way to recognising the suffering inflicted upon its First Peoples as a consequence of colonisation. Such historical reassessment of the nation’s origins has given rise to a backlash of unsettlement. Australia’s History Wars feature claims and counter claims regarding the number of Aboriginal people intentionally murdered by colonists as distinct from ‘unintentional’ Indigenous fatalities resulting from introduced infectious diseases. Following recent critiques of the ‘virgin soil’ hypothesis in context of the Columbian Exchange (for example Cameron, Catherine M., Paul Kelton, and Alan C. Swedlund, eds. 2015. Beyond Germs: Native Depopulation in North America. Tucson: University of Arizona Press.), I argue that biological determinism has similarly obscured the violence of Australian settler colonialism. Focussing on observations of a mid-nineteenth century outbreak of smallpox in Australia’s Northwest, I seek to expand the horizons of debates concerning the scope and extent of settler colonial violence to include the appraisal of introduced diseases as a form of structural violence.
